theslyestfox: After working retail for many years I realized that 99% if women feel this same way about their bodies. It doesn’t matter what their size or shape is — we’ve all been told by advertisers that we aren’t good enough but we need their products to be prettier, skinnier, healthier, etc for so long that no matter what we look like, most of us still feel this way. One of my best friends thinks she’s ugly and overweight...and she’s a tiny size 4 — and a millennial. But she’s beautiful and strong and independent and amazing beyond her looks too. Working in stores dressing women of all sizes the #1 thing women hated about their bodies was their ARMS. Even the slimmest, strongest, smartest women were self conscious about that skin that hangs and moves when you wave. I hope you’re right that finally this is starting to change, and younger generations won’t feel this way, and that having people of all shapes sizes and talents in the spotlight and on fashion spreads will help. I hope for a future where we can all be happy with our bodies and realize that we are all beautiful and strong no matter what.

oliandc: “Comparison is the thief of joy.” -Teddy Roosevelt You have so much strength in your body. Thank it for keeping you alive. It works so hard to make sure that happens, nothing else should matter. You have lived through and done so much in your short time on this Earth and you still have so much more joy to share. We are in this life once, don’t waste it worrying about something that you inherited. I am by no stretch considered a beautiful woman by American standards. I am Cuban/Ecuadorian-American and I am 5’4 and over weight, olive complexion with black hair. There are so many things I see and want to change, but then I think of where my body came from, the people who gave me my hair, my height, my muscles, my nose, my teeth, my indigenous features. I am here because they survived. That’s beautiful to me. Whenever I think about changing something, I think of them and how I am a part of them and then I don’t want to change anything at all.

mobaker_: Currently dealing with this exact thing as an engaged woman. Finding my wedding dress has been a true nightmare of huge proportions. I don’t want white or cream or blush or ivory - and that’s hard enough. But I’m also a size 14, and that’s proving even harder. I feel totally shamed and pushed into a box I don’t fit in. Totally a burden to ever bridal shop I walk in. Like they’re thinking, “ugh she’s too fat to be in love and happy. We can’t help her.” It’s been the most horrendous experience during a time that is supposed to feel joyful. I just want to wear my cozy pants and Strong Female Lead shirt and say fuck the rest. Thanks for speaking up and out about not feeling represented or wanted and about moving through the shame of those feelings. ♥️
